title: Essex truck deaths: Police charge man with 39 counts of manslaughter
text:
A man from Northern Ireland has been charged with 39 counts of manslaughter, Essex Police say, over the bodies found in a truck on Wednesday morning.

Maurice Robinson, 25, is also being charged with "conspiracy to traffic people, conspiracy to assist unlawful immigration and money laundering" and will appear in court on Monday. Three other people have been arrested in connection with the investigation, while another man, detained in Ireland, is thought to be of interest to investigators.

It comes as photographs of 20 missing Vietnamese have been handed to UK authorities amid uncertainty over the nationality of the victims.

Essex Police originally said those found in the lorry were "believed to be Chinese nationals".

But later — and after the Vietnamese Embassy in London said it had received calls from citizens fearing they had relatives on the truck — the force said that they could not "realistically speculate" on the nationality of the victims.

Now VietHome, a UK-based organisation that assists the local Vietnamese community, has forwarded pictures of missing people from the Asian country to authorities.

"We quickly tried to assess [the nationality] in the very early few hours with getting onto the back of the lorry but in doing so we couldn't disturb the evidence that was in there," explained Detective Chief Inspector Martin Pasmore.

"We cannot realistically speculate at this time about the nationality of all of our deceased within that vehicle," Pasmore said on Saturday.

"We gave an initial steer on Thursday on nationality however this is now a developing picture," Essex Police's Deputy Chief Constable Pippa Mills said in a statement on Friday.

Essex Police said that they were engaging with the Vietnamese community and working to identify the victims and reunite them with their families as quickly as they could.

Pasmore said they were getting a lot of information from the Vietnamese and said they had agreed with Vietnam's ambassador that they would share fingerprint information to identify victims.

On Friday, police said they had made a fourth arrest in the case, and on Saturday, Irish police, the Gardai, arrested a man in his 20s who was linked to the case, according to RTE.

Vietnam's prime minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc ordered an investigation into the situation and instructed the embassy in the UK to "monitor the situation" and work with UK authorities to confirm any victims' identities.

He also told his ministries to look into cases of human trafficking and to report back to the government by November 5.
